dialogue.text: Daddy, what if there's nothing to figure out?
Maya asks me: 'Daddy, what if there's nothing to figure out?' I tell her she's already wiser than I was at forty.
You know, I spent twenty years trying to figure myself out before realizing what you just said.
But everyone's always trying to figure things out. Like there's going to be a test or something.
Maybe we're like them. Doing our thing without needing to see the whole picture.
I think people make up things to figure out because they're scared of just being.

psychological_notes: Maya demonstrates the fruit of being raised with uncertainty as friend. Her insight 'nothing to figure out' deconstructs entire self-help industry and existential anxiety in one phrase. Shows how wisdom can arise naturally when not corrupted by cultural pressure to know oneself definitively.
philosophical_underpinning: The deepest truths are often the simplest, seen clearly by unconditioned mind
therapeutic_direction: Liberation from the compulsion to solve oneself
